cluster_relations.rel_desc: The combined protective spines and hairs structure includes spines as a component.
The combined protective spines and hairs structure includes hairs as a component.
Butterflies possess a proboscis as a mouthpart.
Plants have flowers as their reproductive structures.
remarks: Part–whole relation is implied by description, not spelled out as 'part of'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The car door handle is a component of the car door.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on the exterior of the car door
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Function: mechanism to open the car door

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject entity includes the object entity as a physical component or substructure.
args.justification: All four relations describe whole entities (caterpillar defensive structures, butterfly, plants) that include other entities (spines, hairs, proboscis, flowers) as their components. The natural direction is whole → part, so a single canonical predicate 'has_part' with a generic part–whole description fits all of them.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject entity is a physical component or substructure of the object entity.
args.justification: This relation explicitly states that the car door handle is a component of the car door, with the subject being the part and the object the whole. This is the inverse direction of 'has_part', so a separate canonical predicate 'part_of' that reflects the part → whole direction is appropriate.

All five relations, whether expressed as whole → part ('has_part') or part → whole ('part_of'), represent physical part–whole (mereological) structure: components such as spines, hairs, proboscis, flowers, and door handles in relation to the larger structures they belong to. Grouping them under a single class 'part_whole_relation' captures this shared semantics.
Part–whole relations describe how entities are composed of components or belong as components to larger structures, which aligns with a broad COMPOSITION dimension in the schema.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Subject entity includes the object entity as a physical component or substructure.
executed_decisions.justification: All four relations describe whole entities (caterpillar defensive structures, butterfly, plants) that include other entities (spines, hairs, proboscis, flowers) as their components. The natural direction is whole → part, so a single canonical predicate 'has_part' with a generic part–whole description fits all of them.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The escaped criminal has a hook instead of a hand.
The collective imagination is a component or attribute of society.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Psychological and Cultural Constructs of Urban Legends

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject entity includes the object entity as a physical or conceptual component.
args.justification: The escaped criminal is described as physically possessing a hook in place of a hand, a clear part-whole relation where the subject includes the object as a component.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject entity is a component, aspect, or subset of the object entity.
args.justification: The collective imagination is described as a component or attribute of society, a conceptual part-whole relation where the subject is a constituent of the broader object.

Both relations describe mereological structure: one where the subject has a component (has_part) and one where the subject is a component of a larger whole (is_part_of). Grouping them under a shared part-whole relation class is appropriate despite opposite directionality.
Both links describe how entities are composed from, or include, other entities (physical body part vs. conceptual aspect of society), which fits the broad COMPOSITION dimension.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Communities aim to protect their loved ones.
Communities seek to protect against perceived threats by sharing tales.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Urban Legend Emotional Themes and Responses

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: via narrative sharing and collective awareness
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: from perceived threats, real or imagined

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ethical principles aim to protect communities as part of prioritizing their well-being.
remarks: Relation derived from the phrase including communities as beneficiaries; somewhat redundant with the composite well-being entity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject safeguards or provides protective benefit to the object (actual or intended protection), often against implicit or explicit threats.
args.justification: Both relations describe an agent (communities; ethical principles) providing or intending to provide protection to beneficiaries (loved ones; communities). The protection is the subject's effect on the object, so a single canonical predicate 'protects' with a description that allows for intended or actual protection fits both.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject seeks or attempts to obtain protection against or from the object, which is construed as a source of potential harm or threat.
args.justification: This relation encodes a different direction of protection semantics: communities are not protecting threats, but instead are seeking protection from perceived threats. Using a distinct canonical predicate 'seeks_protection_from' preserves the asymmetric role of the threat as the source of harm.

All three relations concern protective dynamics and safety: subjects either protect others or seek protection from threats. Grouping them under a shared class 'protection_and_safety_relation' captures this common semantic family while allowing distinct canonical predicates.

Protection relations encode causal or counterfactual effects (subject's norms or actions reduce or mitigate potential harms from threats). This aligns best with a high-level CAUSALITY group rather than generic association, since the key semantics is about causal mitigation of risk or harm.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Laying eggs on the underside of leaves serves to protect the eggs from predators.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Plant Structures as Lepidopteran Substrate and Background

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when eggs are laid on the underside of leaves

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Camouflage protects caterpillars by concealing them from predators.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in environments where predators hunt visually
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Mechanism: visual blending with twigs or leaves

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillar spines serve as protective structures against predators.
remarks: Predators are not explicitly named in the same clause but implied by surrounding text about camouflage from predators.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hair-like structures on caterpillars provide protection against predators.
remarks: Specific target (predators) is inferred from nearby phrase about predators.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject trait, structure, or behavior confers protection to a target (typically the organism or its offspring) by reducing harm or risk posed by the object (e.g., predators, environmental hazards).
args.justification: All four relations describe traits or spatial behaviors (underside egg placement, camouflage, spines, hairs) that functionally protect caterpillars or their eggs by reducing the threat posed by predators. The shared semantics is that the subject provides a protective effect against the object, so a single predicate 'provides_protection_from' generalizes across these cases.
args.remark: The protected entity (e.g., caterpillar, eggs) is captured in qualifiers or surrounding context rather than in the predicate itself.

args.justification: Each relation links a defensive trait or behavior (egg placement on leaf underside, camouflage, spines, hairs) to the threat it defends against (predators). Grouping them under 'defensive_trait_relation' captures that these are functional defense relationships rather than generic associations.

The subject traits causally reduce predation risk; they are not merely co-occurring with predators but function to protect from them. This is best modeled as a causal defensive effect from subject to object (threat).

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: final stage of the life cycle

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The butterfly has a pupa stage as part of its life cycle.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: pupa stage of the butterfly life cycle

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The pupa stage comes before the adult stage in the butterfly life cycle.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: pupa stage of the butterfly life cycle

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StageOrder: pupa is the third stage, adult is the fourth

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The pupa stage is described as the third stage within the butterfly's life cycle.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: pupa stage of the butterfly life cycle

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: third stage of the life cycle

cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StageOrder: fourth and final stage of life cycle

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The newly emerged adult butterfly represents the beginning of the adult life stage.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: immediately after emergence from the chrysalis
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: implicit mapping from individual to life stage

remarks: Direction chosen as individual (newly emerged adult) being part of the stage.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The adult stage is a specific life stage of the butterfly.
The pupa stage is one of the sequential life stages of the butterfly.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: pupa stage of the butterfly life cycle

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: between larva and adult butterfly stages
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: SequencePosition: third stage in the described life cycle

remarks: Relation generalized from the listed life cycle sequence; life cycle entity itself is not explicitly modeled here.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The adult stage represents the final life stage of the butterfly.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: final stage in the life cycle
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: SequencePosition: fourth and final life cycle stage

remarks: Sequence context suggests direction stage → organism.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism or individual is currently in a specific life stage within its life cycle.
args.justification: All three relations link a butterfly (or an individual butterfly) to a particular life stage as a state it is in, rather than describing sequence or causality. They share the same semantics of an entity being in a life stage, so a single predicate 'in_life_stage' is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a specific life stage belongs to and is part of the life cycle of a given organism.
args.justification: These four relations all connect a life-stage entity (pupa or adult stage) to the organism (butterfly) whose life cycle it is part of. The direction is consistently stage → organism, representing a life-stage membership relation, so a single predicate 'is_life_stage_of' suits all of them.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that one life stage occurs before another life stage in the ordered life cycle of an organism.
args.justification: This relation explicitly encodes temporal order between life stages (pupa before adult) within the life cycle, not general causality or membership. A specific temporal-order predicate 'precedes_in_life_cycle' best captures this semantics.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a biological process culminates in or brings about a particular life stage of an organism.
args.justification: This relation connects the process of metamorphosis to the adult life stage as its outcome, emphasizing a causal transition rather than simple sequence or membership. The predicate 'results_in_life_stage' correctly encodes a process → resulting life stage relationship.

All these relations describe membership or association between an organism (or individual) and its life stages, in either direction (organism → stage or stage → organism). Grouping them under the class 'life_stage_membership_relation' captures this shared semantics across different canonical predicates and directions.

This relation encodes the ordered succession of life stages (pupa before adult), which is fundamentally about temporal order between states in a process. The broader class 'temporal_order_relation' appropriately groups such precedence relations.

The metamorphosis → adult stage link represents a transition in the life cycle where a process produces a new life stage. Classifying it as a 'life_cycle_transition_relation' distinguishes it from mere membership or ordering and captures its process-to-stage transition character.

All these relations concern life stages and their position or membership within the life cycle, which is inherently temporal (stages as time-bounded phases; one stage preceding another). Grouping them under 'TEMPORALITY' reflects their primary semantic dimension.

The relation between metamorphosis and the adult life stage is described as one leading to or resulting in the other, which is a causal transition rather than simple co-occurrence or ordering. The broad group 'CAUSALITY' best captures this process → outcome semantics.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Governments are potential actors that may engage in abuse of power enabled by surveillance technologies.
remarks: Direction chosen as actor (government) toward act (abuse of power).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Corporations are also potential actors that may engage in abuse of power enabled by AI surveillance.
remarks: Parallel to relation for governments.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a potential actor that may commit or engage in the specified abusive or harmful act, without asserting that it necessarily occurs.
args.justification: Both relations link institutional actors (governments, corporations) to the same act ('abuse of power') with an explicitly potential / non-deterministic modality in the context of AI-enabled surveillance. A generalized predicate 'may_commit' captures this actor-to-harmful-act relation cleanly and can be reused for other potential-perpetrator links.
args.remark: The potentiality is already captured in the canonical_rel_name; detailed conditions (e.g., AI-enabled surveillance) stay as qualifiers on the relation instances.

args.justification: These relations specify which entities can play the role of perpetrator of a harmful/abusive act (abuse of power), fitting a role-based actor-to-harm class. The class name 'harm_perpetrator_role_relation' groups this with other potential or actual perpetrator-role links.

The core semantics is about which agents (governments, corporations) may perform a given act (abuse of power). This is primarily an actor/agency relation rather than pure causality or composition, so it best fits the AGENCY group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Providing explanations for AI system decisions is essential for building trust in AI systems.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when explanations are provided as part of transparency efforts
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Mechanism: explanations of decisions and processes

remarks: Relation focuses on the role of decision explainability, though explanations themselves are implicit.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Explanations of AI system decisions and processes contribute to ensuring accountability.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when explanations are provided as part of transparency measures
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Mechanism: explanations of AI decisions and processes enhance traceability

remarks: Accountability here is achieved via the broader notion of transparency, operationalized through explanations.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Addressing accountability-related issues contributes to ensuring AI is developed and deployed in a responsible and ethical manner.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in development and deployment of AI technologies

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Establishing clear ethical guidelines promotes development and deployment of AI in a responsible and ethical manner.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in AI technologies development and deployment

remarks: Responsible and ethical manner is partly implied from the previous sentence; relation inferred across adjacent sentences.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Regulations, alongside ethical guidelines, promote responsible and ethical development and deployment of AI.
remarks: Responsible and ethical manner is not repeated explicitly with regulations but is implied by shared construction with guidelines.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject factor causally contributes to or makes possible the realization of the object outcome (typically a governance, trust, accountability, or ethical-quality state).
args.justification: All five relations express a positive causal contribution from a governance- or norm-related concept (explainability of AI decisions, accountability measures, ethical guidelines, regulations) toward higher-level outcomes (trust in AI, accountability, responsible and ethical AI development and deployment). The surface forms 'supports', 'contributes_to', and 'promotes' are semantically equivalent enabler relations in this context and can be consistently normalized to a single predicate 'enables'.

Each relation links an AI governance or normative construct (explainability, accountability, ethical guidelines, regulations) to desirable ethical or governance outcomes (trust, accountability realization, responsible and ethical AI practice). They all belong to the same family of causal-enabler relations within AI ethics and governance, so a shared class 'ethical_governance_enabler_relation' is appropriate.

The descriptions and qualifiers (e.g., 'essential to building', 'contributes to ensuring', 'promotes') indicate causal or enabling influence from the subject to the object, rather than mere association or identity, thus they should be grouped under the broad causal dimension.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Oral storytelling facilitates the intergenerational transmission of tales.
Interconnected societies facilitate the spread of urban legends.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: became more interconnected through trade and travel

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The internet enables rapid sharing and dissemination of stories.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: In the age of the internet

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Social media platforms enable rapid sharing of stories.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: In the age of … social media

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject enables or makes easier the spread, transmission, or dissemination of the object (stories, tales, legends, or similar informational content).
args.justification: All four relations describe an enabling/causal role where the subject (oral storytelling, interconnected societies, internet, social media) makes it easier for stories, tales, or legends to be transmitted or spread. A single predicate 'facilitates_spread_of' captures this causal-enabling semantics consistently across instances without overfitting to a specific medium or speed.

Each subject entity functions as a mechanism or context that enables the dissemination of narrative or informational content. Grouping them under 'information_dissemination_enabler_relation' captures the shared conceptual family of relations where something acts as an enabler of information spread.

The relations all encode that the presence or operation of the subject causally contributes to or enables the spread/transmission of the object; this is best modeled as a causal/enabling dimension rather than mere association.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The spread of urban legends extends across continents.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: FormVariation: various narrative forms and variations

remarks: Uses Hook Man as a representative instance of urban legend spread.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates the geographic extent or coverage area over which a phenomenon, process, or dissemination (such as the spread of urban legends) occurs.
args.justification: All three relations link the spread of urban legends (a dissemination phenomenon) to geographic scopes (regions, continents, around the world) with rel_hint_type='spatial reach'. A single predicate 'has_spatial_reach' consistently captures that the subject's extent is the specified spatial area.
args.remark: Normalized previous variants like 'occurs_in' and 'reaches' into one spatial-extent predicate.

args.justification: Each relation expresses the extent of spread or dissemination in space rather than a simple location membership. Grouping them under 'spatial_reach_relation' distinguishes these from generic location/occurs_in relations.
The core semantic dimension is spatial: how far the urban legends spread geographically (regions, continents, around the world). This fits the broad spatial category.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: During the pupa stage, the chrysalis (pupa) is attached to a plant stem, situating the stage on that substrate.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: pupa stage of the butterfly life cycle
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Plant Structures as Lepidopteran Substrate and Background

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: when forming the chrysalis at the start of the pupa stage
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: implied correspondence between chrysalis and pupa stage

remarks: Relation created to capture spatial context of the pupa/chrysalis relative to the plant stem.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The young couple is situated in a secluded area.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: typically, at the start of the tale
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeRole: initial setting of the legend

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The scratching sound is heard on the car door.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is situated at, on, or within the spatial region or physical substrate denoted by the object.
args.justification: All three relations express a generic spatial placement of the subject relative to the object: the pupa stage on a stem, a couple in a secluded area, and a scratching sound on a car door. Using a unified predicate 'located_at' abstracts over prepositional nuances ('in', 'on') while preserving semantics; specific wording remains captured in SpatialQualifier.

Each relation links an entity to the spatial location or substrate where it is situated or perceived. Grouping them under 'spatial_location_relation' captures that they are all about where something is located in space, independent of narrative domain or biological vs. fictional context.
All relations encode spatial context (placement on a stem, in an area, on a car door). This clearly aligns with a high-level spatial dimension rather than composition, causality, or other groups.

Each relation links an entity to the spatial location or substrate where it is situated or perceived. Grouping them under 'spatial_location_relation' captures that they are all about where something is located in space, independent of narrative domain or biological vs. fictional context.
All relations encode spatial context (placement on a stem, in an area, on a car door). This clearly aligns with a high-level spatial dimension rather than composition, causality, or other groups.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Regulations are designed to apply to and govern AI systems during their development and deployment.

args.justification: Both relations express that a governance instrument (ethical guidelines or regulations) specifies its scope of application over AI systems during certain lifecycle phases. They share the same predicate semantics from a norm to its governed entity, so they should be normalized under one canonical predicate.
args.remark: Lifecycle phase is captured via qualifiers; the core predicate remains the scope of application from guideline/regulation to AI systems.

args.justification: In both cases, the relation encodes the scope of governance or applicability of a normative instrument (guidelines or regulations) over AI systems, which fits a shared class for governance scope links.
These relations concern regulatory/ethical control and applicability over AI systems, which is best captured as a broad governance-oriented group rather than composition, causality, or spatiality.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Twig mimicry involves resembling twigs in appearance.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Leaf mimicry consists of resembling leaves in appearance.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: visual environment where leaves are present

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject is a type of mimicry strategy that visually resembles the object in appearance or form, typically for camouflage or concealment.
args.justification: Both relations describe specific mimicry strategies (twig mimicry, leaf mimicry) whose defining property is visual resemblance to the referenced plant structure (twigs, leaves). The common predicate is visual resemblance, without implying genetic or taxonomic identity, so a generic appearance-based resemblance predicate is appropriate and reusable.

These edges both describe biological mimicry where one entity (a camouflage strategy) is defined by its resemblance to another entity (a background plant structure). Grouping them under a mimicry-focused resemblance class captures this shared mechanism and distinguishes it from other resemblance or identity relations.

The core semantic dimension is similarity/likeness of appearance between subject and object, i.e., a form of identity or equivalence in visual traits, rather than composition, causality, or spatial location. Thus these belong best under a broad identity/similarity group.
args.remark: Could alternatively be modeled under an ASSOCIATION-like group in future if a separate similarity group is introduced.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The truth behind the stories is conceptually contrasted with fictional elements in the tales.
remarks: Relation added to reflect contrast; less explicit than fact-truth link.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two narrative elements or concepts are set in opposition or conceptual contrast to highlight their differences.
args.justification: All three relations explicitly encode a contrast between two narrative concepts (varying story specifics vs. stable emotional themes; truth vs. fiction). They share the same symmetric predicate meaning of conceptual opposition, so they should use a single normalized canonical predicate 'contrasts_with'.

Each relation captures a conceptual opposition between two narrative constructs (e.g., variable specifics vs. constant fear/threat, truth vs. fiction). Grouping them under a class 'conceptual_contrast_relation' reflects this shared function of highlighting opposing concepts within narratives.

Contrast is a form of comparative association between two concepts, linking them by highlighting their differences. This is neither compositional nor causal but a relational comparison, which fits best under a broad 'ASSOCIATION' group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ethical guidelines help mitigate potential harms from AI technologies.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: Under governance guided by ethical guidelines
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: potential (harms may or may not occur)

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Regulations are part of the measures aimed at mitigating potential harms from AI technologies.
Promoting accountability helps mitigate potential harms arising from AI technologies.
Developing and deploying AI in a responsible and ethical manner serves to reduce or mitigate harms from AI technologies.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: During development and deployment of AI technologies
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: potential (harms may be mitigated but not fully eliminated)

remarks: Direction chosen as responsible manner leading to reduced harms; reverse direction (harms motivating responsibility) is also plausible but less directly expressed.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject causally reduces the likelihood, severity, or impact of the specified harms, without necessarily eliminating them.
args.justification: All four relations describe governance or ethical mechanisms (ethical guidelines, regulations, accountability, responsible and ethical manner) that causally reduce or mitigate potential harms from AI technologies. Despite minor wording differences ('mitigates', 'reduces/mitigate'), the semantic predicate is the same: the subject mitigates the harms represented by the object.
args.remark: The harms are AI-specific in these instances, but the canonical predicate is kept general so it can be reused for other harm domains.

args.justification: Each relation links a governance/ethics/control mechanism to the reduction of AI-related harms, which is a classic risk mitigation pattern rather than generic association or composition. Grouping them under 'risk_mitigation_relation' captures that they are mechanisms intended to mitigate risks/harms.

All relations express a causal effect where the subject (guidelines, regulations, accountability, responsible manner) leads to a reduction of harms. Mitigation and reduction are inherently causal notions, so CAUSALITY is the most appropriate high-level group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Developers are proposed as possible bearers of accountability when AI systems err or cause harm.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: when an AI system makes a mistake or causes harm
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if an AI system makes a mistake or causes harm
qualifiers.CausalHint: when ... makes a mistake or causes harm

remarks: Relation primarily captures that developers are candidates in accountability allocation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Users are proposed as possible bearers of accountability when AI systems err or cause harm.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: when an AI system makes a mistake or causes harm
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if an AI system makes a mistake or causes harm
qualifiers.CausalHint: when ... makes a mistake or causes harm

remarks: Potential, not asserted, responsibility.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The AI system itself is proposed as a possible locus of accountability for its mistakes or harms.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: when an AI system makes a mistake or causes harm
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: if an AI system makes a mistake or causes harm
qualifiers.CausalHint: when ... makes a mistake or causes harm

remarks: Highly debated concept; here only noted as a considered option.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is considered a possible bearer of accountability or responsibility for outcomes associated with an AI system, without asserting that accountability is actually assigned.
args.justification: All three relations describe different actors (developers, users, the AI system itself) being considered as possible loci of accountability when an AI system causes mistakes or harm. The semantics are identical: the subject is a candidate to carry accountability, not definitively assigned. A single canonical predicate that captures potential/considered accountability improves consistency and distinguishes it from definite responsibility.
args.remark: Canonical predicate explicitly encodes that accountability is only potential or under consideration, aligning with the qualifiers indicating open questions and conditional scenarios.

args.justification: Each relation concerns how accountability or responsibility for AI system errors or harms might be allocated among different possible subjects. This is more specific than a generic responsibility relation and captures the normative allocation dimension across multiple candidate bearers.
args.remark: This class can also group other predicates about assigning, distributing, or contesting accountability around AI outcomes.

args.justification: The core semantic dimension is about who holds or may hold responsibility/accountability for AI system outcomes, which fits a broad group focused on responsibility and liability rather than causality, composition, or identity.
args.remark: If a standardized global vocabulary is later adopted, this group could be aligned with any higher-level category for responsibility/liability in governance ontologies.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Corporations are described as the holders of the concentration of power enabled by AI.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in the hands of a few corporations

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject holds, owns, or has control over the object (which can be a tangible asset, power, or an abstract attribute such as fears or anxieties).
args.justification: Both relations describe a possession/holding relationship: (1) society as the bearer/holder of collective fears and anxieties, and (2) corporations as holders of concentrated power. A unified predicate 'possesses' cleanly captures this ownership/control semantics with the subject as possessor and object as possessed entity.

Both instances concern who has or holds something (fears; concentration of power). This fits a common class of relations about possession or control over attributes, resources, or powers, regardless of whether they are material or abstract.

Possession and control relations indicate which actors (society, corporations) are agents that hold or control certain properties or powers, aligning best with an AGENCY-oriented group among broad semantic dimensions.

Normalizing these to a single predicate 'is_subtype_of' yields a consistent hierarchical edge in the KG.

Each relation encodes a taxonomic or type hierarchy where the subject is a more specific subtype, kind, or characteristic state of the object. Grouping them under a shared class 'taxonomic_subtype_relation' captures this family of hierarchical 'is-a' style links.
All four relations describe hierarchical organization (subtype / kind-of / specific form) between subject and object, which belongs in a broad hierarchy-oriented relation group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject exerts a shaping influence on how the object develops or changes over time.
args.justification: Both relations describe cultural factors (interests or fears of different cultures) shaping how tales evolve over time, i.e., exerting an influence on the evolution of stories.
args.remark: Use this predicate when some cultural or contextual factor shapes the development trajectory of narratives.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject affects the audience's belief or questioning regarding the existence or reality of the object.
args.justification: This relation instance explicitly concerns how blurring fact and fiction affects listeners' questioning of the existence of the supernatural, i.e., an influence on belief about the object.
args.remark: Use this predicate for narrative or informational factors that alter belief or doubt in some concept or entity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject (a story form or folklore domain) captures the attention or interest of the audience.
args.justification: Both relations describe narrative forms (supernatural tales or modern folklore) captivating or drawing interest from audiences, which is the same engagement effect with audiences as objects.

args.justification: These links describe how cultural factors causally shape the evolution of narratives, a specific family of influence relations focused on story development over time.

args.justification: This relation is specifically about influencing belief or doubt regarding the existence of something, fitting a belief-oriented influence class distinct from narrative evolution or simple engagement.

args.remark: Use for relations where stories or media capture attention, curiosity, or sustained interest of audiences.

args.justification: In both relations, 'ethical dilemmas in AI development' is the broader concept and the object (surveillance purposes, biased data) is a specific ethical issue that is part of that set; this is a category-membership relation from category to member.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject is a specific ethical issue or concern that is part of, or discussed within, the broader set or category of ethical dilemmas in AI development (the object).
args.justification: In these three relations, the subject (job displacement, inequality, concentration of power) is a concrete ethical concern that belongs to the broader concept 'ethical dilemmas in AI development' (object), expressing membership from member to category.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Decision-making processes are expected or designed to achieve fairness.
Decision-making processes are expected or designed to achieve equity.
Ethical principles are intended to prioritize the well-being of individuals and communities affected by AI.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: EthicalOrientation: focus on human and community welfare

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process, policy, or framework is designed or expected to pursue a particular normative objective or outcome.
args.justification: Both relations describe decision-making processes being designed or expected to pursue specific normative goals (fairness and equity). A normalized predicate 'aims_to_achieve' better captures this intentional, goal-oriented semantics than the raw 'aims_for' wording and can be reused for similar normative objectives.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a principle, policy, or system gives higher normative importance to a particular value or outcome when guiding decisions or behavior.
args.justification: This relation states that ethical principles give special priority to the well-being of individuals and communities when guiding AI development. executed_decisions.remark: Slight inferential nature is already captured in the UncertaintyQualifier; predicate still models object identity.

executed_decisions.justification: The relation asserts that two mentions (bloody hook, hook for a hand) are the same physical hook, belonging to an identity/equivalence family.
Semantics concern reference and sameness of an entity, which falls under identity rather than causality or composition.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates a non-causal, conceptual association between two ideas or domains.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation reflects that research on the origins of urban legends is conceptually tied to questions about the truth behind the stories, with no direct causal or identity claim.
The link is a broad conceptual association between two research/idea areas, fitting an association-type class.
This is best modeled as an associative/relational tie between concepts rather than identity, causality, or spatiality.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject stands in a correspondence relation to the object, typically aligning or matching it in meaning or truth-value, without strict identity of reference.
executed_decisions.justification: The description states that 'truth behind the stories' corresponds to factual, verifiable aspects; this is a correspondence between a truth-claim and facts rather than literal object identity.
The predicate specifically captures a truth–fact correspondence notion, which fits a correspondence-style relation class distinct from general conceptual association or strict identity-of-object.
Philosophically this encodes a truth-as-correspondence-to-fact view; it is closer to an identity/accuracy dimension than to mere association, even though it is not strict token-identity.
executed_decisions.remark: Could also be modeled under ASSOCIATION in alternate schemas, but identity-of-truth-to-fact is a reasonable primary grouping here.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The conceptual line between fact and fiction is defined as a boundary that separates factual content from non-factual content.
The conceptual line between fact and fiction separates fictional content from factual content.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a conceptual or categorical boundary separates the subject from the object, distinguishing them as different domains or categories.
args.justification: In both relations, the subject is the conceptual 'line between fact and fiction' and the object is either 'fact' or 'fiction'. The semantics are identical: the boundary separates one domain from the other. A unified predicate 'separates_from' captures this conceptual boundary relation for both directions consistently.
args.remark: Used for conceptual or categorical boundaries, not just physical separation.

args.justification: Both relations describe a conceptual boundary that distinguishes two narrative categories (fact vs. fiction). Grouping them under 'conceptual_boundary_relation' captures the family of relations where one entity serves as a boundary or separator between conceptual domains.

args.remark: Could alternatively be modeled under a specialized conceptual-structure group in future schema refinements.

args.justification: The relation describes predatory strangers focusing on children as intended victims (with luring as a causal hint); a directed, intentional targeting for potential harm is the core predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a narrative or communicative artifact serves to alert an audience to specific risks, harms, or dangers.
args.justification: The subject is stories and the object is dangers; the description and hints emphasize alerting and warning, so a communicative predicate capturing that stories warn about particular dangers is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity is exposed or vulnerable to potential harm or danger from another entity, whether the threat is real or perceived.
args.justification: The relation explicitly encodes loved ones as potentially threatened by perceived threats; the core semantics are vulnerability to a threatening agent or condition, including imagined ones.

Both relations model directed threat dynamics between an actor or threat and a vulnerable party: in one case predators target children, in the other loved ones are threatened by perceived threats. They differ in direction and surface form but share the same conceptual family of threat–victim/vulnerability relations.
This relation connects stories to the dangers they alert audiences to; its primary function is to capture communication of risk or danger rather than direct threat or composition.

Both relations encode potential or implied harmful effects: a targeting agent can cause harm to children, and perceived threats can cause potential harm to loved ones. They sit in a causal/threat dynamic rather than simple association or identity.

args.remark: Although the second description notes that transformations can span multiple stages, the instantiated relation is specifically tying them to the pupa stage, which still fits 'occurs_during'.

This is a recurring pattern linking biological processes to organismal life stages, best captured as a dedicated class 'life_stage_occurrence_relation' rather than a generic temporal relation.
The core semantics is that the processes happen during a specific time-bounded life stage (pupa), making this a temporal occurrence relation rather than causal, compositional, or spatial.

The semantic focus is on the butterfly as an active agent performing an action (its first flight), which falls under agency/participation rather than composition.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a particular life stage includes or is characterized by a specific event or milestone.
args.justification: The subject is the 'adult stage of a butterfly' and the object is the milestone event 'first flight'; this is not an agent performing an action but a life stage being composed of/characterized by that event.
The relation specifies what event is included within or characteristic of a particular life stage, which is a compositional relation internal to life-cycle stages.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a constituent or component of the object, which is a larger whole or system.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject, typically a group or community, consists of or includes the members represented by the object.
args.justification: The subject 'communities' and the object 'people around the world' indicate a group–member composition where the community is composed of its people; modeling this as 'has_member' keeps directionality clear (whole → member).

Both relations describe compositional structure: ecological processes as parts of the natural world, and individuals as members of communities. Despite opposite directions (part→whole vs whole→member), they belong to the same conceptual family of part–whole/group–member relations.

All three relations describe how larger entities or stages are composed: life stages by events, the natural world by ecological processes, and communities by people. These are clearly compositional/part–whole semantics.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Pollination enables or helps plants to reproduce.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject functionally enables or facilitates the occurrence or success of the object process/state, without implying strict determinism.
args.justification: All three relations describe a functional enabling or facilitating effect: (1) fully developed wings enable first flight, (2) butterflies facilitate/enhance pollination, and (3) pollination enables plant reproduction. Using a single predicate 'enables' captures this causal-functional support consistently while remaining agnostic to deterministic vs. contributory causation.

Each relation expresses that the subject provides a functional capability or support that causally contributes to the object (wings → flight, butterfly → pollination, pollination → plant reproduction). Grouping them under a functional_causality_relation class cleanly abstracts this family of enabling/ facilitating links.
In all cases the subject is presented as a causal factor for the object outcome or process (enabling or facilitating it), so they fall naturally under a broad CAUSALITY group.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Mechanism: acting as food source and pollinators

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: EpistemicContext: educational or observational study of butterfly life cycles

remarks: Relation abstracts from 'life cycle of butterflies' to the butterfly entity due to available entity set.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an animal visits a plant structure (e.g., flowers), typically for feeding or other resource acquisition.
args.justification: The relation describes butterflies visiting flowers to obtain nectar; a simple predicate 'visits' correctly captures the ecological visitation behavior between animal and plant structure.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an agent moves or carries biological material (e.g., pollen) from one location or organism to another.
args.justification: The description explicitly states that butterflies transfer pollen between flowers during pollination; the predicate 'transfers' is appropriate and reusable for agent-mediated movement of material.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity plays a role in producing, maintaining, or influencing an ecological or system-level property (e.g., biodiversity).
args.justification: The text states that butterflies contribute to the biodiversity of their ecosystem; the predicate 'contributes_to' accurately captures this causal-influence relation toward a system-level variable.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that studying or considering an entity helps reveal, explain, or improve understanding of another concept or process.
args.justification: The relation describes how studying butterflies helps reveal and appreciate ecological connections and processes; this is an epistemic/educational facilitation rather than a direct ecological interaction, so 'facilitates_understanding_of' best captures the intended meaning.

Both relations describe direct ecological interactions between butterflies and plant-related resources: visitation to flowers and transfer of pollen during pollination. Grouping them under 'ecological_interaction_relation' reflects organism–organism/resource interactions.

The relation links butterflies to biodiversity, an ecosystem-level state variable, emphasizing their functional role in the ecosystem rather than a specific pairwise interaction. 'ecosystem_function_relation' captures this contribution to ecosystem properties.

The relation is about how studying butterflies helps reveal and understand ecological connections, which is an epistemic/knowledge-oriented link rather than a direct ecological or physical interaction. 'epistemic_relation' captures this informational role.
Both relations capture direct ecological interactions where butterflies engage with flowers and pollen; these are classic biotic interaction links, fitting the broad 'INTERACTION' group.
The statement that butterflies contribute to biodiversity encodes a causal influence of the organism on an ecosystem property, appropriately categorized under 'CAUSALITY'.

The relation concerns how studying butterflies reveals or improves understanding of ecological processes, which is an informational/epistemic effect rather than a direct physical or ecological interaction, fitting an 'INFORMATION' group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Denotes that a process causally leads to a specific outcome state, structure, or life stage.
args.justification: All relations describe biological processes (molting or metamorphosis) causally producing an outcome (new skin, new tissues, wings, antennae, or an adult butterfly). They are all process→outcome links differing only in the specific outcome type, so a unified causal outcome predicate 'results_in' is appropriate and consistent across instances.
args.remark: More specific predicates like 'results_in_formation_of' or 'results_in_change_of' can be captured at the description/qualifier level if needed; the core schema predicate here is a generic process outcome relation.

args.justification: Each relation links a biological process (molting or metamorphosis) to its biological outcome (changed integument, newly formed tissues or organs, or a new life stage). This fits a common class of relations where a biological process yields a specific biological outcome.
In all cases, the subject process is explicitly described as leading to or producing the object outcome, which is a causal process→effect pattern, so they belong under a broad causal relation group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity currently possesses or is in a particular physical or experiential state.
args.justification: The relation links the newly emerged adult butterfly to the condition of its wings being soft and wrinkled, which is best modeled as the butterfly having a specific state.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a specific state description to the underlying entity or part whose state it describes.
args.justification: The subject is the soft, wrinkled state of the wings and the object is the general wing entity; this is a classic state-to-entity relation and matches the directionality of 'is_state_of'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or action causes a change from one state to another in the target entity.
args.justification: The fluid pumping process causally transforms the wings from a soft, wrinkled state to an expanded, hardened state, which is best captured as inducing a state change in the wings.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity manifestly displays or expresses a particular state (e.g., aesthetic, behavioral, or experiential) under certain conditions.
args.justification: The butterfly is described as displaying an aesthetic state (beauty and grace) when fluttering by, which is well modeled as the butterfly exhibiting that state.
All three relations link entities (butterfly or butterfly parts) to descriptive states of those entities (physical or aesthetic), without focusing on the transition between states.
This relation specifically captures a process that changes an entity from one state to another, which is a state transition rather than static state attribution.

These relations associate entities with the states that describe them (physical or aesthetic) without an explicit causal or temporal transition focus, fitting a broad association/attribution dimension.
The relation encodes that the fluid pumping process causes the wings to change from one state to another, which is inherently causal.

args.justification: Both relations describe metamorphosis as a causal process that changes or dissolves specific body structures (caterpillar body, organs), focusing on morphological transformation of anatomy rather than the final life stage outcome.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A biological process results in the organism reaching or becoming a particular life stage or form.

All three relations model causal links within an organism's developmental process (metamorphosis) either changing body structures or producing a new life stage, so they fit a shared class for causal relations in biological development.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an anatomical structure or life stage gradually changes and becomes another anatomical structure or life stage over the course of development.
args.justification: This relation connects the caterpillar body to the butterfly as an end-stage of metamorphosis, describing a developmental progression rather than a simple material conversion. The predicate 'develops_into' captures life-stage morphological development with temporal progression.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a material or structure is converted into another material or structure, emphasizing physical or morphological transformation.
args.justification: This instance describes the caterpillar's organs dissolving and becoming a soupy substance. The focus is on a physical conversion of material rather than a life-stage progression, so 'transforms_into' is the most precise predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that one material or anatomical substrate serves as the developmental source or precursor from which another tissue or anatomical structure forms.
args.justification: All three relations describe the soupy substance as the substrate from which new tissues, wings, and antennae form during metamorphosis. The semantics are developmental origin/precursor, so a single normalized predicate 'is_developmental_source_of' cleanly covers all of them in the same direction (source -> derived structure).

Both relations describe morphological or material transformation of one anatomical entity into another state (body into butterfly, organs into soupy substance). Grouping them under 'morphological_transformation_relation' captures this shared family of developmental/physical change predicates (develops_into, transforms_into).

These relations consistently express that the soupy substance is the precursor material from which specific anatomical structures form. This fits a shared class describing developmental origin or precursor–product relationships between substrate and resulting tissues.

All relations encode that one entity brings about or materially results in another (body causing butterfly form, organs becoming soupy substance, soupy substance generating new tissues and structures). These are best viewed as causal/developmental origin or transformation links, fitting the CAUSALITY group.

The qualifiers already encode conditionality and modality (e.g., 'can', 'if'), so a single canonical predicate 'causes' appropriately captures the underlying causal semantics across these instances.

Each relation instance expresses that one factor has a causal effect on another outcome (e.g., biased data leading to discriminatory outcomes, lack of transparency leading to distrust). Grouping them under the class 'causal_effect_relation' captures this shared semantic of directed causal influence without restricting it to a specific domain beyond causality.
All relations involve a directional causal link where one factor leads to or sustains another harmful outcome or state, fitting squarely into the broad semantic group of CAUSALITY.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Flowers provide pollen that can be transferred between them.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject biologically produces or generates the object as a material or resource (e.g., a plant structure producing nectar or pollen).
args.justification: In both relations, flowers are the biological structures that generate the resource (nectar or pollen). The semantics are about biological production/origin from the flower, not just generic provision. Using a single predicate 'produces' normalizes these closely related instances.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject entity generates or produces the object entity as an output or result.

Both relations describe a producer–product linkage: flowers producing pollen, and AI systems producing decisions. Despite opposite predicate direction in one case, they share the same conceptual family of a process or agent yielding an output.

In both cases, the producer causally leads to the existence of the product (pollen caused by flowers, decisions caused by AI systems). This is best captured as a causal/processual link rather than mere association.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject serves as a food resource for the predator group represented by the object within a trophic interaction.
args.justification: In all three instances, the subject is the 'food source role of butterflies' and the objects are predator groups (birds, reptiles, predatory insects). The semantics are that butterflies (via this role) are eaten by these predators, i.e., they serve as a food source for them. A single predicate 'is_food_source_for' consistently captures this trophic relation from the perspective of butterflies as prey/food, independent of predator taxon.

Each relation connects a prey food-source role (butterflies) to predator taxa and is explicitly marked as 'trophic' in the hints. These are specific cases of predator–prey feeding interactions, which are well captured by a shared class 'trophic_interaction_relation'.

The relations describe ecological predator–prey feeding relationships between butterflies (as a food source) and various predators. These are best modeled at the broadest level as biotic interactions rather than composition or causality, so the INTERACTION group is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject functions as an enticing or attractive element that draws the attention or presence of the object, often in a narrative or instrumental context.
args.justification: This relation instance describes candy functioning as an enticement that attracts children in cautionary legends. A concise predicate-focused label like 'lures' better captures the directional semantics (bait -> target) than the upstream wording, while remaining reusable for similar bait/enticement edges.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject gives rise to or generates the existence or proliferation of the object.
args.justification: Both relations describe abstract cognitive-cultural sources (collective imagination, creativity) producing the proliferation of urban legends. They share identical causal direction and type (source generates outcome), so they should use a single canonical predicate; 'generates' is more general and reusable than 'produces'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject helps maintain or uphold the ongoing existence, intensity, or vitality of the object over time.
args.justification: Both relations describe ongoing background factors (mysteries, fears) that keep the collective imagination and the thriving of urban legends active. They clearly share the same sustaining/maintaining semantics, so a unified canonical predicate 'sustains' is appropriate and directionally clear.

All five relations connect psychological, cultural, or narrative factors (candy as bait, imagination, creativity, mysteries, fears) to either children as targets or to the existence/proliferation of urban legends and the collective imagination. They represent causal or quasi-causal links within the domain of urban legends, so grouping them in a shared class focused on causation within this domain is appropriate.

Each relation encodes a cause–effect style dependency: candy lures children; imagination and creativity generate legends; mysteries and fears sustain the collective imagination and thriving of legends. This fits squarely into a broad CAUSALITY category rather than association, composition, or other groups.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject functions as an enticing or attractive element that draws the attention or presence of the object, often in a narrative or instrumental context.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation instance describes candy functioning as an enticement that attracts children in cautionary legends. A concise predicate-focused label like 'lures' better captures the directional semantics (bait -> target) than the upstream wording, while remaining reusable for similar bait/enticement edges.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject gives rise to or generates the existence or proliferation of the object.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe abstract cognitive-cultural sources (collective imagination, creativity) producing the proliferation of urban legends. They share identical causal direction and type (source generates outcome), so they should use a single canonical predicate; 'generates' is more general and reusable than 'produces'.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject helps maintain or uphold the ongoing existence, intensity, or vitality of the object over time.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe ongoing background factors (mysteries, fears) that keep the collective imagination and the thriving of urban legends active. They clearly share the same sustaining/maintaining semantics, so a unified canonical predicate 'sustains' is appropriate and directionally clear.

All five relations connect psychological, cultural, or narrative factors (candy as bait, imagination, creativity, mysteries, fears) to either children as targets or to the existence/proliferation of urban legends and the collective imagination. They represent causal or quasi-causal links within the domain of urban legends, so grouping them in a shared class focused on causation within this domain is appropriate.

Each relation encodes a cause–effect style dependency: candy lures children; imagination and creativity generate legends; mysteries and fears sustain the collective imagination and thriving of legends. This fits squarely into a broad CAUSALITY category rather than association, composition, or other groups.

Adult butterflies perform reproduction to continue the life cycle.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity serves as a participant or material involved in a biological or physical process.
args.justification: The subject 'pollen' is a reproductive material that takes part in the process 'pollination'; the semantics are that it participates in the process rather than causing or merely co-occurring with it.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism actively performs or executes a biological process or behavior.
args.justification: The subject 'butterfly' is the organism that carries out the process 'reproduction of butterflies'; this is best modeled as an organism performing a biological process.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a subject possesses a particular attribute, property, or characteristic.
args.justification: The relation describes that 'people around the world' are characterized as having 'imagination'; this is a classic subject–attribute relation and should be normalized as a generic attribute predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an informational or cultural item circulates, is shared, or is transmitted within a given population or community context.
args.justification: The subject 'modern folklore' is said to circulate within 'communities'; the semantics are dissemination of cultural content within social groups, well captured by 'circulates_in'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a subject enables, accelerates, or facilitates the dissemination or spread of a piece of information, content, or phenomenon.
args.justification: The subject 'communication platforms and media' are described as facilitating the 'proliferation of urban legends'; the key semantic is enabling their spread, not merely co-existing with them.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process, phenomenon, or state occurs within or is embedded in a particular contextual setting (e.g., societal, cultural, spatial, or temporal).
args.justification: The 'proliferation of urban legends' is said to occur within 'modern society'; this is a contextual containment/setting relation rather than a causal or compositional one.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a problem, risk, or dilemma is addressed, reduced, or managed through the application of a given principle, method, or mechanism.
args.justification: The relation states that 'ethical dilemmas in AI development' are to be managed by 'ethical principles'; this is best captured as the dilemmas being mitigated or addressed by those principles.

Both relations link biological entities (pollen, butterflies) to biological processes (pollination, reproduction) in which they take part, either as material participants or active performers; they naturally fall into a shared class of participation in biological processes.
The relation connects 'people around the world' with the characteristic 'imagination', clearly expressing a subject–attribute link that fits an attribute-focused relation class.

Both relations concern how cultural content (modern folklore, urban legends) moves or spreads: one describes circulation within communities, the other how platforms facilitate spread; together they form a coherent class of cultural dissemination relations.
The relation specifies that the proliferation of urban legends occurs within the contextual setting of modern society, which is best grouped as an occurrence-in-context type relation.

The link between ethical dilemmas and ethical principles is normative and governance-oriented: principles are prescribed to manage or mitigate dilemmas; this warrants a governance/mitigation relation class.
Both relations capture entities participating in biological processes; this fits a broad participation-oriented semantic dimension rather than pure causality or composition.
The relation encodes that people possess a mental characteristic (imagination), which falls squarely into an attribute/characterization semantic dimension.
Both relations concern how cultural narratives move and spread through social or technical channels; dissemination is the primary semantic axis here.
The proliferation of urban legends is located within the contextual space of 'modern society'; this is best modeled using a broad spatial/contextual grouping.
The relation encodes how ethical principles are employed to manage or mitigate ethical dilemmas in AI development, which is strongly aligned with governance and normative control.
